issue.title: Savefiles to EEPROM in Homebrew Games

comment.body:
> Godmode9i (a homebrew app) runs on hardware (an execution environment) and utilizes [dkp EEPROM calls](https://github.com/devkitPro/libnds/blob/master/include/nds/card.h) for dumping save files from cartridges

you can run it from unlaunch in melonDS DSi mode with a cartridge inserted and it should already work in melonDS.

issue.title: Savefiles to EEPROM in Homebrew Games

comment.body:
> As there is no real world homebrew execution environment which uses EEPROM,
Well, Godmode9i (a homebrew app) runs on hardware (an execution environment) and utilizes EEPROM for dumping save files from cartridges. Obviously it's pointless to emulate this on melon, but I think C3RVI (and my) use cases (supporting EEPROM calls as a fallback in non-DLDI environments) isn't unreasonable particularly, and is supported & works great on DESMUME (which has lacklustre DLDI support from my experience).

I agree with your point of principle though, but think homebrew games that want to use EEPROM should be able to, particularly given how unstable DLDI/libfat can be (homebrew using EEPROM works on DESMuME, too, for instance).

issue.title: Can't connect to Wiimmfi servers (A replacement for Nintendo WFC)
issue.body: I cant connect to [Wiimmfi](https://wiimmfi.de/) servers to play online* since the Nintendo WFC

comment.body: there are some known ISP related issues which makes patching the rom a requirement to connect to WFC replacement servers for some people.

issue.title: Can't connect to Wiimmfi servers (A replacement for Nintendo WFC)
issue.body: I cant connect to [Wiimmfi](https://wiimmfi.de/) servers to play online* since the Nintendo WFC

comment.body: I just tested with melonDS 0.9.5 running Mario Kart DS, and it works great. Just search for an access point in your Nintendo WFC settings and add the `melonAP` access point as a connection. After that, change the DNS in the access point's settings to Wiimmfi, which is currently 167.86.108.126, just as you would on a real DS.

pull_request.title: Add optional support for Tracy
pull_request.body:
[Tracy](https://github.com/wolfpld/tracy) is a frame profiler that is intended to be integrated directly into a game (or emulator, or other application). It has minimal overhead, and can be conditionally compiled out.

I use it in melonDS DS, but I needed to be able to instrument parts of melonDS itself. So I added Tracy to the build process, optionally. No extra steps are required, it's fetched with [`FetchContent`](https://cmake.org/cmake/help/latest/module/FetchContent.html). To enable Tracy, set the `TRACY_ENABLE` option in CMake to `ON`.

Here are some examples of Tracy's output:

![Screenshot 2023-10-25 102908](https://github.com/melonDS-emu/melonDS/assets/1175189/2fb129d6-615e-443a-bca7-9d0b559fef78)
![Screenshot 2023-10-24 193152](https://github.com/melonDS-emu/melonDS/assets/1175189/80583db8-fcc9-4c49-ad9d-583ae9f4281b)

It's helping me diagnose a race conditions issue that's causing [this bug](https://github.com/JesseTG/melonds-ds/issues/81) as well.

commits.message:
Miscellaneous DSi NAND fixes (#1852)

* Replace some standard I/O calls with Platform equivalents

- I missed a spot when I submitted that PR a few months ago

* Include <memory> in DSi_NAND.h

- Because it uses unique_ptr

* Split DSi_NAND::ReadHardwareInfo into ReadSerialData and ReadHardwareInfoN

* Add a RegionMask enum

* Move DSi NAND patching to the frontend

* Add DSiSupportedLanguageMask

- Not currently used by the frontend, but I use it in melonDS DS

* Remove some Platform::ConfigEntry values

- The core no longer needs to know about them
- The corresponding Config values are unchanged

* Mark NANDMount's destructor as noexcept

pull_request.title: Miscellaneous DSi NAND fixes
pull_request.body:
This PR adds a few small fixes to the DSi NAND code that I'd been planning to introduce.

- Replaces some standard I/O calls (`fopen`, etc.) with `Platform::FileHandle` equivalents. I missed a spot when I submitted that PR a few months ago.
- Add some enums for representing regions and languages, and update the appropriate `struct` fields that use them. Upstream melonDS doesn't use these, but I intend to use them in melonDS DS. My use case is twofold:
  - I intend to stop the player from installing DSiWare games from incompatible regions
  - If the player's language is set to something that the current NAND doesn't support, then it will fall back to some other language. (Usually English, but not always.)
- Add an `#include` that should've been there.
- Move DSi NAND userdata patching to the frontend. Being able to control when and how this happens is important to me, because of some additional features I'm planning.

commits.message:
Slight polish to DMA (#1856)

* Slight polish to DMA

- Default-initialize members explicitly
- Mark some methods as const noexcept
- Initialize DMA::MRAMBurstTable to DMATiming::MRAMDummy
- Use the default destructor

* Move DMA_Timings definitions to a source file

- To ensure constant and unique addresses

* Include some extra DMA members in the savestate

* Simplify serializing the DMA table

- Extend the dummy table to 256 bytes (same length as the real ones)

* Revert the type change to DMA::DoSavestate

* Keep the MRAMBurstTable inside the DMA class, instead of using a pointer

- If we use a pointer to an external table, then we can't use it in savestates (else that external table gets overwritten)

pull_request.title: Slight polish to DMA
pull_request.body:
[Someone encountered a crash](https://github.com/JesseTG/melonds-ds/issues/87) in the melonDS DS libretro core, and I narrowed down the cause to an uninitialized variable in `DMA`. That crash occurs when auto-loading a savestate (which occurs within a frame or two of loading the ROM); since you can't manually load savestates that quickly in upstream melonDS, this issue hasn't had any impact there.

This PR makes some minor fixes to `DMA`, including:

- Default-initialize members explicitly
- Mark some methods as const noexcept
- Initialize DMA::MRAMBurstTable to DMATiming::MRAMDummy
- Use the default destructor

~~**Note:** I have not tested this PR yet. My current `HEAD` relies on [this unrelated PR](https://github.com/melonDS-emu/melonDS/pull/1852), so I can't test it with this one until #1852 is merged.~~ Tested it on a separate branch. Works like a charm, resolves the crash I identified.

pull_request.title: Protect savestates while the threader renderer is running
pull_request.body:
In upstream melonDS, the frontend has full control of when it takes savestates, so you can assume that the render thread won't try to run while a savestate is being taken or loaded.

I can't make that assumption, as libretro doesn't let cores control when savestates are taken. End result is [this issue](https://github.com/JesseTG/melonds-ds/issues/81), which this PR aims to fix.

But it's not done yet, so don't merge it.

issue.title: Feature request: launch most recent ROM on startup
issue.body: I think pretty often you're going to want to launch the most recent game you used on startup. It would be nice if there was an option to relaunch whatever you were playing on startup. This could be done via a checkbox in emu or interface settings and would be pretty convenient. To avoid issues with a corrupted or otherwise broken ROM rendering melonDS unusable a potential solution would be to write a flag to disk prior to loading a ROM and then if melonDS stays alive for more than say 5-10 seconds or closes gracefully you can remove it, then when you go to automatically load the ROM you have an idea of whether or not it is likely to cause problems.
